Language is hard.
The sounds are incredibly distinct, especially the dotted and undotted letters like i and ı—they make a world of difference!
Learning the common honorifics and polite phrases (buyurun!) instantly opens doors to local kindness
There's no grammatical gender (no he or she in the third-person singular). It simplifies things a lot
Turkish uses the Latin alphabet, thanks to Atatürk's reforms. It's much easier to start reading than you'd think.
The best part is the vowel harmony. It's an internal rhythm that makes the language flow so musically.
The grammar is entirely agglutinative, meaning words are built like LEGOs by stacking suffixes. One word can be a whole sentence!
Vowel harmony makes it sound so smooth and rhythmic.
Die Agglutination ist eine Herausforderung, aber logisch.
